Chapter on Encouraging Acceptance of Worldly Benefits, Part 2
At that time, after the night had passed, the Bodhisattva put on his robes in the morning, and leisurely proceeded from Mount PÄá¹‡á¸ava to the city of RÄjagá¹›ha in order to beg for alms.

Observing the suffering, emptiness, and impermanence of the aggregates, he wished to seek the great nirvÄá¹‡a without remainder. Looking at the ground one fathom ahead, he subdued his faculties and completely eliminated and severed the places of defilement, not allowing any stains.
He further thought like this:
I am now begging for alms, but I do not have a bowl. If I obtain food, where will I put it?
At that time, the Bodhisattva looked around in all directions for a vessel but did not find one.
Suddenly he saw a large flower pond in one place. Having seen it, he immediately said to a person beside him:
Good man!
You may beg from me the lotus leaves of this pond.
Having heard this, the man immediately entered the pond, picked a lotus leaf, and offered it to the Bodhisattva.
At that time, the Bodhisattva accepted the lotus leaf and went to the city to beg for food.

At that time, the people inside and outside the city of RÄjagá¹›ha, seeing the Bodhisattva's careful consideration like this, and seeing the Bodhisattva's majestic and lofty spiritual power, each gave rise to a greatly rare mind and said to each other:
This is the three-eyed MaheÅ›vara who has come here.
Among them, there were some travelers who wanted to do business and went to other places. Having seen the Bodhisattva, they turned back and went to where the Bodhisattva was.
Or there were some people who wanted to do something, but on the way, having seen the Bodhisattva's appearance, they abandoned their work and came to the Bodhisattva.
If there were people sitting, having seen the Bodhisattva, they unconsciously got up, quickly came to, and went to where the Bodhisattva was.
Or there were people who joined their palms in respect and single-mindedly faced the Bodhisattva.
Or there were those who bowed their heads to the Bodhisattva, or those who said to the Bodhisattva with subtle sounds:
Welcome, welcome!
At that time, in the city of RÄjagá¹›ha, all the people who saw the Bodhisattva did not have a single thought of unhappiness or dislike.
In the city of RÄjagá¹›ha, there were people with many tongues, speaking in confusion and frivolous words, but in front of the Bodhisattva, they remained silent and followed the Bodhisattva's steps.

Moreover, in the city of RÄjagá¹›ha, all around in the four directions, whether men or women, husbands or wives, who wanted to do other things, all stopped to watch, giving rise to a rare state of mind, watching the Bodhisattva, their eyes unblinking.
The bodhisattva that they observed, from his limbs, face, forehead, eyes, shoulders, neck, hands, feet, and gait, each and every place was delightful, and they were unable to look at any other place.

At that time, the bodhisattva was in the prime of youth, delightful and upright, in the time of the flower-like beauty of life, and left home to renounce the world, with the tuft of white hair between his eyebrows curling to the right, his eyebrows fine and long, his eyes wide and large, his majestic virtue filling everywhere.
His body was radiant, lofty and majestic, illuminating far and near, with a net-like pattern on his hands and feet, all completely covering.
His twenty fingers were well able to govern and transform all gods and humans. The majestic spiritual power of the bodhisattva was unequaled in the world.
There is a verse that says:
When the bodhisattva walks on the road, all those who see him,
Only see a part of his body's radiance, and upon seeing it, they immediately give rise to love and attachment.
His eyebrows are fine and raised like the new moon, his eyes are blue-black like an ox king,
His body always emits great radiance, and his fingers and toes have webbed membranes.
Those who see his subtle and wonderful appearance follow him without realizing it,
Gazing at this marvelous and adorned form, each gives rise to great joy in their hearts.
At that time, the city-protecting deity of RÄjagá¹›ha, seeing the Bodhisattva with such demeanor, was frightened and uneasy, thinking:
What great deity is this?
He wants to come and take away my seat here.

At that time, the Bodhisattva, surrounded by countless people on the left and right, some following behind and some in front, watched as he slowly and steadily proceeded towards RÄjagá¹›ha, wishing to beg for alms.

In all movements, whether looking up or down, advancing or stopping, they are dignified and composed. They walk with light steps, neither slow nor fast, with focused eyes looking straight ahead, their senses restrained. Their arms and elbows are straight and even, their robes neat and proper, holding a lotus vessel whose leaves do not wither.
With a mind of tranquil concentration, people see them with joy. Supreme and most excellent, they attain Å›amatha, gentle and harmonious.
Like a well-tamed elephant, they are free from turbidity and defilement;
Like a pure pond, they radiate light at all times, a fathom away from the body;
Like a Å›Äla tree with its many flowers in full bloom;
Like a golden elephant emerging from the ground, fully endowed with all the marks of adornment;
Like the stars surrounding the moon and sun in the night sky, the bodhisattvas illuminate the world.

At that time, the people of RÄjagá¹›ha all gave rise to great joy and a rare state of mind. Seeing the Bodhisattva walking in the streets and alleys, the merchants and traders in the city all stopped their business and no longer bought or sold.
If they were in a shop, intoxicated and confused, they all became sober and no longer drank alcohol. They abandoned all the sounds of their feasts and ran to the Bodhisattva's place.
Some followed him to the left and right to observe him, some looked back while walking in front of him, and some followed behind the Bodhisattva.

In the city of RÄjagá¹›ha, countless women, leaning against doors, standing in windows, on towers, or on rooftops, who had previously made a living, now did not do so, all abandoned their work and watched the Bodhisattva from afar.
House after house, people came out and were delighted. They said to each other:
Who is this now?
Where did you come from?
To which clan do you belong?
What is your name?
We have never seen anyone so upright, delightful, and graceful as you.
Are you a monk?
Or a brahmin?
Your appearance is like this, your bearing is extraordinary.
The sound of praise spread throughout the city.
At that time, the king of Magadha, the lord of RÄjagá¹›ha, whose clan name was ÅšrÄ«bhadra and personal name BimbisÄra,
before becoming king, had made five vows:
First, may I attain the throne early in my youth.
Second, if I attain the throne, may a Buddha appear in the world within my realm.
Third, if the Buddha appears in the world, may I personally serve and make offerings to him.
Fourth, if I am able to serve him, may he only teach the Dharma as appropriate for me.
Fifth, if the Buddha preaches the Dharma for me, after hearing the Dharma, may I not slander it, and after attaining realization of the Dharma, may I rely on it and practice it.

At that time, King BimbisÄra was sitting on a high building surrounded by ministers. He saw from afar the Bodhisattva being led by a great assembly, peacefully proceeding, and entering the city of RÄjagá¹›ha.
BimbisÄra, having seen the Bodhisattva, gave rise to great doubt. He immediately came down from the building and went outside the palace gate.
He saw the Bodhisattva's body, bearing himself with dignity, upright and unparalleled, like the many stars in the night sky, loved and enjoyed by all who beheld him.
Like a maá¹‡i jewel, with light inside and out, transparent through and through, the Bodhisattva's body was also like this, with majestic virtue blazing and shining brightly.
At that time, King BimbisÄra, having seen the Bodhisattva's appearance like this, ordered the ministers, saying:

'Since my birth, I have never seen a person with such a physical appearance, complexion, and facial features, with a broad and flat forehead, pure and clear, shining brightly like a lotus leaf in the water, not stained by the water.

This body has majestic virtue, with hair curling to the right, a tuft of white hair between the eyebrows like pure lapis lazuli, also like white shell or foam, with the color and radiance complete like a full moon disc.

The soles of his two feet tread on the ground with a thousand spokes, with patterns appearing as he lifts his steps, his footprints not shifting, not frightened, not startled, not trembling, not shaking, his wisdom peaceful and still like Mount Sumeru.
From where did he come, suddenly arriving here?
You ministers should observe and see whose family line he is from.
Whose son is he?
In which country was he born?
What is his name?
He is upright and pleasing, traveling through here.
At that time, the ministers said among themselves:
'This is the Heavenly King.'
Some said:
'It is Åšakra.'
Some said:
'It is a great dragon king.'
Some said:
'It is the Asura King Vemacitrin.'
Some said:
'It is the Asura King Bali.'
Some said:
'It is the world-protecting god king VaiÅ›ravaá¹‡a.'
Some said:
'This is the sun god.'
Some said:
'It is the moon god.'
Some said:
'It is MaheÅ›vara.'
Some said:
'This is BrahmÄ.'
There were also other brahmins who were good at divination who said:
'Great King!
You should know that according to our theories, this person will definitely become a wheel-turning sage king.
Why is it so?
Now this great being's body is filled with all the characteristics.
At that time, among the great assembly of ministers, there was another minister who said to the king:
Your Majesty!
You should know that this is indeed the case.
Why is it so?
Not far from here, ten yojanas to the north, under the Himalayas, there is a clan called ÅšÄkya.
The ÅšÄkya clan has a country called Kapilavastu.
In that country, there is a king named Åšuddhodana, who is the king of the ÅšÄkyas.
That king has a son named SiddhÄrtha, who was born into the ÅšÄkya clan and has the surname Gautama.
When that prince was first born, the king immediately summoned the physiognomists and brahmins to have him examined.
When the physiognomists had finished examining him, they said to the great king:
Great King!

You should know that this prince now possesses two kinds of characteristics. If he stays at home, he will certainly accomplish the status of a wheel-turning sage king, rule the four continents, protect the great earth, and rule the world according to the Dharma;
If he abandons the royal status, he will definitely attain the status of a TathÄgata, Arhat, Samyak-Saá¹ƒbuddha, and his name will be renowned in the ten directions.
Great King!
You should know that this must be that prince, without a doubt.
Why is it so?
That person has now shaved his beard and hair, his body is golden in color, he wears a kÄá¹£Äya robe, has left the country to go forth, and has come here wandering.
And he spoke a verse, saying:
The physiognomists of that country said these words: 'He will not occupy the royal status, but will definitely become a Buddha.'
This is definitely that son of the ÅšÄkya clan, who has left the household life, practices austerities, and seeks enlightenment.
At that time, after the great minister had said this, King BimbisÄra thought to himself:
'If it is as I have vowed in the past, then my wish will be fulfilled.
' King BimbisÄra then ordered the two ministers:
'If you know, quickly go and see in which direction this renunciant is staying.
In which place is he?
After you have investigated, quickly report to me, and then I shall go there myself to observe, make offerings, and receive teachings I have not heard before.'
At that time, the two ministers, having received the king's order, immediately followed the Bodhisattva's direction and went, not letting go for a moment.
At that time, when the Bodhisattva was begging for food in the city of RÄjagá¹›ha, he saw the great assembly filling all directions. He thought to himself:

'With such skillful means, this great assembly has no refuge, no savior, no protector. They are always bound by birth, old age, sickness, and death, yet they are not afraid, not alarmed, not terrified, and do not know how to seek the ultimate path. They have no guide.

They are foolish, deluded, and confused. They are submerged in afflictions, ignorant and lacking wisdom. Day by day they diminish, attached to the aggregates, suffering, emptiness, and impermanence, not knowing how to be disgusted with them.'
At that time, after the Bodhisattva had this thought, he gave rise to a mind of compassion and increased his diligence and courage even more. He subdued his mind and thought like this:
'I will now become the refuge for all worlds. I will save and protect the suffering world. I will speak for the world the end of birth, old age, sickness, and death.'

At that time, the Bodhisattva raised his eyes and only looked at the yoke in front of him, silently and intently watching, slowly moving his steps, his appearance dignified, he went around the city of RÄjagá¹›ha, begging for food in order.
Having obtained food, he calmly left the city of RÄjagá¹›ha and gradually arrived at Mount PÄá¹‡á¸ava.
At the foot of the mountain, there was a spring pond. He sat by the water, mindfully and peacefully, eating whatever coarse or fine food he had obtained, in accordance with the Dharma.

After eating, he put away his robe, washed his hands and feet, and then went up to the top of Mount PÄá¹‡á¸ava. Having arrived, he looked to the south of the mountain, seeking a forest with wonderful branches and leaves, lush and dense, with many birds and beasts flying and running about, playing, with flowers, fruits, and springs.

In between good trees, he spread out grass and sat down, facing east, his body upright and mind focused, sitting in the full lotus position, dignified and still, just like a lion entering a cave, fearless and unalarmed.
Wearing the kasaya robe, its radiance was brilliant, lofty and majestic, blazing and shining, like the newly risen sun.
There was a verse that said:
That mountain is lush with abundant trees and forests, birds and beasts frolicking and enjoying various pleasures,
The person wearing the kasaya robe is as radiant as the newly risen sun.
At that time, the Bodhisattva sat under that tree and thought like this:
In this place where I study, there are no other people, no pudgala, no sentient beings, no life-endurers, no life-possessors, no sentient beings, no humans, no young men, no one to be nurtured.
These five aggregates are all empty, without life or consciousness. All dharmas only have provisional names, and are called sentient beings.
At that time, the two ministers sent by King BimbisÄra followed the Bodhisattva, never leaving his side. One minister sat not far from the Bodhisattva,
while the other quickly returned to King BimbisÄra of Magadha.
Having arrived, he knelt for a long time and said to the king:
'Great King!
You should know that the renunciant, after begging for alms in RÄjagá¹›ha, went to PÄá¹‡á¸ava Mountain and sat facing south with his body straight, as previously described.
Great King!
If you wish to see him now, you should go quickly.'
At that time, King BimbisÄra of PÄá¹­aliputra, having heard these words from his messenger, immediately prepared a good and virtuous chariot, sat in it, and went to PÄá¹‡á¸ava, driving quickly.

At that time, King BimbisÄra arrived at the mountain and saw from afar the Bodhisattva, who was delightful and upright, his mind was extremely fond of him, to the point of being like the many stars in the night sky, like a great bonfire on a dark mountain peak, like the flash of lightning coming out from a great cloud.
King Magadha saw the Bodhisattva under the tree, it was also like this.

Having seen him, he gave rise to a greatly rare mind, his joy pervaded his entire body, and his body hair all stood on end. He dismounted and went on foot to the side of the Bodhisattva. Having arrived, he asked after him and said to the Bodhisattva:
'Are you free from illness and affliction, are the four elements at ease?'
There is a verse that says:
'The king saw the Bodhisattva like Åšakra, his bodily radiance shining, his mind delighted,
Asking after his well-being and the harmony of the four elements, free from illness and affliction, his body without trouble.'

At that time, the Bodhisattva, with his subtle and gentle voice, like the sound of Brahma's voice, with unstained and unattached eloquence and phrasing, spoke to King BimbisÄra of Magadha, comforting and inquiring, saying these words:
'Great King, well-governed!
Great auspiciousness, great good fortune!
From where have you come from afar?
You may sit down and rest.
What is it that you seek that you have come here?'

At that time, King BimbisÄra, having heard these words of the Bodhisattva, advanced before the Bodhisattva, sat down securely on a rock, and in order to fathom the Bodhisattva's intention, said to the Bodhisattva:
'If you, sir, are not weary, I wish to consult and ask about my inner doubts. I only pray that you, sir, will resolve them for me.'
He then asked:
'Who are you, sir?
Are you a god or a dragon?
Are you Brahma or Åšakra?
Are you a human or a spirit?'

At that time, the Bodhisattva, with a mind free from arrogance, greed, and anger, having eliminated all the thorns of afflictions, and with words free from flattery, replied to King BimbisÄra of Magadha, saying:
Great King!
You should know that I am not a god, nor a dragon, nor a brahman, but a human being.
Great King!
It is because I seek tranquility that I have left the household life.
Then King BimbisÄra of Magadha said to the Bodhisattva:
Virtuous monk!
I am now greatly delighted to see you. Therefore, I now wish to ask a question. It is out of my love and respect for you that I wish to speak a single word. Please listen and accept it.
Why is it so?
You are now young, in the prime of life, upright and peerless, with a wonderful body, capable of enjoying yourself and indulging in pleasure;
Why do you now have such thoughts, practicing as a Å›ramaá¹‡a, disgusted with the royal palace, sitting alone in the empty mountains?
Moreover, your body, with such characteristics, is only suitable for applying red sandalwood paste, and should not wear this kasaya robe.

Your two hands are capable of governing the world, with a hundred flavors filling before you, to be eaten and drunk according to the season. How can you hold a begging bowl and go begging from others?
' And he spoke a verse, saying:
'Your body is suitable for applying red sandalwood powder, and should not wear this tattered kasaya robe,
Your fingers are capable of governing the world, how can you beg for food to live from others?'
At that time, King BimbisÄra, having said this, addressed the Bodhisattva, saying:

'If you now do not take the throne out of love and respect for your father, and leave the household life, I now invite you to enjoy the five desires and various necessities in my realm, and will follow your wishes.
I will give you wealth and women.
If you assist me, I will give you half the country to rule. You can stay in my territory and accept my royal position. I will serve you and not let you lack anything.
Why is this?
You, a Å›ramaá¹‡a,
have a soft body and should not stay in empty and secluded places. If you sit on grass mats on the ground, it will harm your body and may cause illness.
But after a short time, your father will decline and you can then take back the royal position of your country.
Therefore, if you now love and pity me, accept my royal position and stay in my territory.
If you, a person of great clan, dislike my narrow territory and impure land, I and my ministers and all the officials will open up another country for you and make it vast. I will rule it with you.
I also wish to obtain a noble family through you, to create causes and conditions together, and to be close relatives.
I hope you will not have doubts, thinking it is not true.
And he spoke a verse, saying:
If you claim a great and noble family, and dislike my narrow territory and are unwilling to stay,
I will together with my ministers and hundreds of officials, further annex and expand it to make it wider.
At that time, King Magadha, having said this, further earnestly said to the Bodhisattva:

I have a heart of love and respect for you, a heart of reverence. Since you, sir, now sustain your body by begging for food, you should just strive to give rise to a broad mind, accept the Dharma, accept wealth, and accept the five desires and pleasures.
Why is it so?

Accepting these three kinds, being in the palace, observing the court ladies, and enjoying pleasures, can also cause one to obtain retribution in the present world, and the same is true for the future.

If a person does not accept these three kinds of dharmas, but only abandons one thing, that person will not be able to fully obtain the fruits and rewards either in the present world or in the future;
even if they accept them, there will certainly be deficiencies.
Therefore, good man!

If you have a magnanimous mind, you should fully accept these three kinds of pleasures. Because of accepting the three pleasures, you should use the time of youth and the fruits of physical beauty to accept the Dharma, accept wealth, and accept various desires.
When a man in the world accepts desires, he gives birth to a child and establishes a family. This is a great wealth.
Therefore, good man, do not let it pass in vain.
Moreover, good man!
Such arms and shoulders are capable of drawing a bow and crossbow. Do not let them be wasted in vain like this in one lifetime.
Moreover, in the past, King MÅ«rdhaja, because of his bravery and strength, ruled the four continents and the Heaven of the Thirty-three.
Such is the capable person, good man.
Why is it so?
I now also exhort and request like this out of compassion for all sentient beings. I do not exhort and request the benevolent one for my own royal position.

I now see that the benevolent one's body is upright, tears of sadness flow, and the mind is unable to bear it. For this reason, I give rise to a mind of rarity even more, and therefore earnestly request like this.
The benevolent one is now in the prime of life, and should first experience worldly desires. Wait until old age, when it is time to practice the Dharma, then one can abandon the household.
Moreover, benevolent one!

From your ancestors up to now, within your own clan, when one reaches old age, one then relies on the laws of the country, entrusts the affairs of the kingdom to the crown prince or a great minister, and only then abandons the position and leaves the household to enter the mountains.
Moreover, benevolent one!

The sages of the past have said, 'When young, one should first engage in sexual activity; in middle age, seek wealth to sustain oneself; only when old and decrepit should one abandon [worldly affairs] and study the Dharma. In this way, one can establish everything.'

Moreover, if a young person does not engage in desires and does not seek wealth, this is an enemy of the body and is also called a thief, destroying the faculties and making them difficult to control.
'Moreover, O Virtuous One!

If a young person wishes to seek the Dharma, it is only because the faculties are drawn to the five desires. When they reach old age, the mind thinks inwardly, cutting off various matters, able to control the faculties, the mind gives rise to shame, and the intention attains tranquility.
'Moreover, O Virtuous One!
In the world, when young people are indulging in negligence, they do not see the long path and have many faults.
When they reach middle age, their blood and energy gradually weaken, and negligence is already past.
It is like a person walking across a vast wilderness, stopping to sigh and say, I have already crossed this place.
Therefore, you are now in the prime of your youth, the time for indulgence, follow your desires to a certain extent, and enjoy pleasures.
Moreover, my good man!

When young, the faculties are difficult to turn back. If you wish to practice the Dharma, to delight in the Dharma, according to your family's ways, make offerings to the gods, and because of making offerings, you will also be reborn in the heavens.
While staying at home, adorn your body, with gold, silver, and various jewels decorating your arms, the light of the jewels shining like bright lamps.
Moreover, my good man!

In the past, the kings wore jeweled crowns, adorned their bodies, always stayed at home, made offerings to the gods, practiced the Dharma, held open assemblies, and some entered the mountains, practiced the great sage's conduct, and sought liberation.
You are now studying with them, acting in accordance with the times.'
King Magadha spoke such various parables and words, skillfully wanting to invite and request the Bodhisattva.

At that time, the Bodhisattva, having heard these words of King Magadha, was neither frightened nor alarmed, neither strange nor different, just like a mountain king, his body and mind unmoving, peacefully abiding, guarding and collecting his faculties, not giving rise to other thoughts, his three karmas pure, he replied to the king.
There is a verse that says:
King Magadha admonishes the Bodhisattva, like friends mutually benefiting each other,
The Bodhisattva's pure three karmas, like a flower unstained by water, he replies to him.'
King Magadha!
Your words are not good, this is said like the words of an ignorant person, not in accord with the words of a king's law in the world.
If the king has a sincere mind towards me, this speech is truly sincere, not deeply beneficial, and not compassionate towards me, but greatly harmful to me.

In the world, there are evil people without compassionate minds, like a wealthy and noble person who is timid. If one wishes to benefit the world, one should teach as in the affairs passed down from the past. This is called a friend, this is called growth.
If a person sees someone in distress and does not abandon them, and the three karmas are the same, this is called a friend. This is my intention.
When someone is wealthy and noble, who cannot be a friend or acquaintance?
If a person obtains wealth and distributes it according to the Dharma, preventing it from being lost, this is called a friend.
This person later, when able to use wealth and teach, they do not take the words, or due to past karma, they lose their wealth themselves and later do not regret it.
If the king considers me a friend and loves and respects me, he should reveal this matter, and I may praise the king or not praise the king.'
At that time, after the Bodhisattva had spoken these words, he further said to the king, 'Great king!
You should know that I now seek the Way, only fearing birth, old age, sickness, and death. For this reason, I wish to seek liberation, so I accept this form.
Relatives and family are truly lovable, respectable, and difficult to abandon. Tears fill their faces, and they weep and lament in distress, or for my sake, they may abandon their lives.
I have already turned my back on them and come to this place. However, the five desires of the world are often due to greed, stinginess, and attachment to unwholesomeness.'
'Moreover, great king!

I am now truly not afraid of poisonous snakes, nor am I afraid of heavenly thunder and lightning, nor am I afraid of the fierce flames of a great fire burning a wilderness blown by a great wind, but I am afraid of being oppressed by the five desires and objects of enjoyment.
Why is it so?
Great King!

You should know that all desires are impermanent, like robbers who steal merits and virtues. They are empty and illusory, appearing in the world, regarded as real when looked at, but in essence they deceive;
Worldly people do not know, and forcefully become attached to them with their minds. How much more so for those who practice the five desires and objects of enjoyment?'
At that time, the Bodhisattva spoke a verse, saying:
The five desires are impermanent and harm merits and virtues. The six sense objects are empty and illusory, harming sentient beings.
The fruits and retributions of the world originally deceive people. Which wise person can temporarily stay?
Fools are not satisfied in the heavens, let alone in the human realm can they be satisfied?
Like a fierce fire burning dry grass.
In the past, King MÅ«rdhaja ruled over the four continents, his golden wheel flying,
And he obtained half of Åšakra's seat, but suddenly giving rise to greedy thoughts, he fell.ğŸ”½Even if one rules this great earth,
The mind still desires to conquer other realms.ğŸ”½Worldly people's indulgence in desires is insatiable,
Like the great ocean receiving all flowing waters.'
At that time, after the Bodhisattva had spoken these words, he further said:
'Great King!

You should know that in the past there was a wheel-turning sage king named King NÄbhÄsa who ruled over the four continents and the Heaven of the Thirty-three, transforming the celestial beings, yet he was still not content.
For this reason, he fell back into the world.
The wheel-turning sage king Ilavati was also like this. He ruled the four continents and the Heaven of the Thirty-three, but because he was not content, he took his life and ended it.
The asura king Vali, having obtained the throne, then fought with Indra and was defeated.ğŸ”½Indra, having obtained it, then turned it over to the wheel-turning king Narayana.
King Narayana, having obtained it, was then again defeated by Indra.
In this way, the realms of the gods and humans are all impermanent. Whose merits are superior?

Up to the edge, if there is a wise person who can contemplate and observe in this way, the impermanent realms change in an instant. How can one believe in this?ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:

There were only the sages dwelling in the mountains and forests, eating various medicinal herbs, roots, fruits, flowers, and leaves, wearing tree bark, or the fur and hides of dead animals, their bodies emaciated, with only skin and bones remaining, wishing to attain liberation and escape from all the sufferings of the world, hoping for the liberation and unconditioned state of nirvana.
If one indulges in the five desires and is bound by them, one will fall back again. What wise person would enjoy and crave this?
If one becomes attached to the five desires, it is like seeking one's own enemy.'
At that time, the Bodhisattva spoke another verse, saying:
The sages dwelling in the valleys, eating fruits, drinking water, and wearing tree bark,
Although their topknots and bodies are emaciated, it is for the sake of seeking liberation and leaving desires.
They are unable to control themselves, and are still dragged along by the five desires,
Such impermanent enemies of desire, the wise should not become attached to them.'
At that time, after the Bodhisattva had spoken these words, he further said:
Your Majesty!
You should know that within the desire realm, one creates union in order to take on the flavors of desire, but after obtaining them, one is not content.
If an ignorant person presently experiences various desires and is not content, he will suffer greatly and will further experience misfortune in the future.
Therefore, a wise person does not grasp onto desirous thoughts.
Thus, a wise person sees that one who practices black dharmas experiences great suffering. If one wishes to be at ease, do not create or enjoy any desires, but should abandon them.
If there is a gathering, one should know that there will be separation.
If one indulges desires to the fullest, the mind becomes lax. If laxity increases, one creates unwholesomeness. If unwholesomeness is accomplished, one will fall into hell.

In past lives, you engaged in great austerities, and now you have attained all desires. But after attaining all desires, you are diligent and protective, yet unable to guard them, and will lose them again.
Moreover, Your Majesty!
If a wise person contemplates like this regarding these desires:
The people and gods in the world are like borrowed things. Since they are impermanent, why be greedy?
All the heavenly and human fruits and rewards are like dew on grass, like the head of a poisonous snake, like the bones of a corpse in a deserted forest.
Also, like a woman's first lump of flesh in the womb, like a dream, like an illusion, like a mass of fire.
In this way, there are many calamities and misfortunes, always oppressed by all kinds of suffering. A wise person should not be attached with a greedy mind.
Moreover, Your Majesty!

When their fathers passed away, they fought among themselves for the throne, killing each other due to the karmic conditions of desire.

Like when the DÄndakas, empty and desolate marshes, were burned by fire, the Alavakas killed various kinds of creatures.
Like the asuras under Mount Sumeru, their brothers each fought for the love of a single jade woman, killing each other in their greed.
'Moreover, it is like a butcher's place, where various kinds of animals are hung on poles and slaughtered.
How can the wise be attached to desires like this?'
Then he spoke a verse, saying:
'In the past, two asura brothers fought over a jade maiden,
Bones and flesh were loved and attached to with hatred. The wise observe and know not to be greedy.'
The Bodhisattva said again:
'Great King!
You should know that there are people who, for the sake of the five desires, wish to be born in the heavens or among humans.
Having been born there, because of attachment to the five desires, they throw themselves into water or jump into fires.
Such impermanence deceives the mind. For the sake of the five desires, one seeks out one's own enemies. What is the point of attachment and enjoyment?'
He also spoke a verse, saying:
The fool, because of love and desire, becomes poor, bound, injured, killed, and suffers various hardships.
Hoping for these desires to accomplish many things, he does not realize that his power is exhausted and that he will suffer in the next life.
The Bodhisattva said again:
King of Magadha!
I know that the five desires are like this, with various faults and harms. You cannot now use these five desires to persuade me.
I now wish to walk the path of fearlessness. If you are a true good friend of mine, you should often admonish me, saying:
The great vows you have made, may they be quickly accomplished, and may you quickly be free from afflictions.
Why is this?

Since I am not being chased by others and entering the mountains and forests, nor am I being driven by enemies, nor have I lost my kingdom and fled, nor am I seeking to return to the ancient sages, therefore I will not accept the king's words now.
Furthermore, great king!
If someone were to hold the head of a venomous snake, let go of it, and then want to catch it again, could they do so?
Is it like a raging fire that burns the hand, let go of it, and then want to catch it again?
It is the same for me. I have already renounced the five desires and left home, and now I want to take them up again, it is also like this.
Furthermore, great king!
How could a person with clear eyes and vision envy a blind and sightless person?
How could a person who is liberated and free from affairs envy a person who is imprisoned and bound by affairs?
How could a person who is wealthy and prosperous envy a person who is poor, hungry, cold, and begs for alms?
How could a person who is clear-minded and wise envy a person who is insane?
